headline: I watched Ole Gunnar Solskjaer at Besiktas – what he did speaks volumes for Man United
body: To a casual observer, it would be easy to cast Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's last foray into management with Besiktas as a failure.

Sacked after just eight months in charge after failing to qualify for either the Europa League or the Europa Conference League doesn't look great on paper for the man in contention to return to Manchester United as interim boss. But that doesn't tell the full story of Solskjaer's time in Turkey, according to football journalist and Besiktas podcaster Kaan Bayazit.

Solskjaer was appointed by a club in crisis one year ago, before lifting them from seventh to a fourth-place finish in the Super Lig. He pulled off a memorable Europa League win over Athletic Bilbao in his first match and beat their arch city rivals, Galatasaray, to retain a proud club milestone.

On the mess Solskjaer inherited 12 months ago, following the sacking of Giovanni Van Bronckhorst, Bayazit told MEN Sport: "It was probably the lowest point I'd seen Besiktas at in my 25 years of following the club. It was a really difficult job to come into.

"It was seen as impossible to win his first game against Athletic Club [Bilbao], who were on a really good run in La Liga and top of the Europa League table. But they played the best football they had played all season and deservedly won 4-1. The start was very positive and got the players on the same page."

Bayazit admits Solskjaer's style of play wasn't easy on the eye but it was case of needs must at the time. He said: "It wasn't great. That was largely due to the limitations of the squad. The football was, at times, decent but never scintillating to watch.

"They only had one true winger. Right after Ole got sacked, they did bring in wingers but he never got to work with those players and I think that's the main reason for the team not being fluid under him.
"He was adamant about the fact that he needed wingers but never got the chance. I think he got the most out of the players for the most part, especially in the big games."

Those big games included a win over Galatasaray that preserved a piece of Besiktas history. Bayazit said: "He's the first manager to win all three big domestic matches in a single half of a season since Besiktas won the league in 2021.

"He beat Fenerbahçe, Trabzonspor and Galatasray. It was Galatasaray's only loss of the season, which was very significant for Besiktas because they're the only 'Invincibles' in Turkish football history, so beating them was very important."

However, Solskjaer still didn't have enough credit in the bank to survive losing in the play-off rounds of both the Europa League and Europa Conference League at the start of the season. Bayazit is adamant Solskjaer didn't deserve the sack and that he was a victim of a president who caved to media pressure.

"I would say he did a great job, even though his tenure had its ups and downs," he said. "I don't think he should have got sacked when he did. I think he did a very good job with the tools he was handed. He had his legs cut from under him by a president who doesn't have the backbone to resist some media pressure.

"I don't think he was sufficiently backed by the president. Two weeks before he sacked him, he said, 'We're backing him.' The president has a tenure for three years, then he has to get re-elected, so there is a lot of pressure on them for instant success.

"But Ole definitely wasn't backed and I would say the Turkish media really had it out for him. Despite the fact he is a model professional and a gentleman, he doesn't leak stuff to the media. He didn't give the media breadcrumbs."

Bayazit saw enough of Solskjaer at Besiktas to suggest he is the right short-term option for United following Ruben Amorim's sacking. He added: "I think it would be great for United. He has the ability to bring that team together again.
"A lot of those players have been told by Ruben Amorim that they aren't good enough. I think that's something Ole will be able to solve short-term.

"I don't know if he is the person to take them back to their glory days. I said the same about him at Besiktas, that I didn't know if he could get us back to winning trophies. But at the time, he was the best option because he stabilised things and brought joy back to the players.

"I think Ole should have been given a lot more time at Besiktas; he could have laid the groundwork for future success with stability around him, which he didn't get. For Manchester United, he is a good option because they're not going to get a top manager at the moment."

As a close follower of English football too, Bayazit believes there are similarities between Besiktas and United. He said: "I've got to know a lot of Manchester United fans recently and the resemblance between them and Besiktas is remarkable, from the state of the squad, backroom politics, the noise around the club, the pressure.

"That's something people who don't follow Turkish football don't realise. The pressure is so much bigger than 95 per cent of football clubs. Only the biggest clubs in the world know the pressure of the three biggest clubs in Turkey. It's from the fans, the media.

"I think Ole did well with the pressure. It's a regretful that he got sacked when he did and it sent the club into more chaos. It speaks volumes about what he did in a relative short period of time, because he did bring some stability. But it got blown up by the president who's very reactionary."

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United player ratings vs Burnley as Benjamin Sesko excellent but one 4/10
body: Manchester United suffered another setback in the race for Champions League football as they were held to a 2-2 draw at Burnley in Darren Fletcher's first game in charge. United started slowly and went behind after 13 minutes. Casemiro was caught out by Bashir Humphreys' run and Ayden Heaven's weak attempt at blocking the cross saw the ball loop in off the centre-back.

Fletcher's side soon took control and two Benjamin Sesko goals in the first 15 minutes of the second half looked to have turned it around. He finished smartly from a Bruno Fernandes pass and Patrick Dorgu cross. Somehow, United let the hosts back into it. They had barely threatened in the second half when Lisandro Martinez let Jaidon Anthony turn and deliver a curling finish.
Here are how the players rated at Turf Moor:
Senne Lammens: Decision to try and read the cross from Humphreys not a good one but powerless with the second goal. Good with the ball at his feet. 6
Diogo Dalot: Tidy in possession and tried to get forward in the second half, but didn't have much of an impact. United's narrow approach didn't get him much of the ball. 6
Ayden Heaven: Turned away from the cross that saw the ball loop in off him, when he should have made himself bigger. Aggressive on the ball at times. 5
Lisandro Martinez: His weakest game since his return to the side. One wild shot and way too passive against Anthony in the area, giving the winger too much space to equalise. 5
Luke Shaw: Got forward well and had an impact in that area. Linked well with Dorgu and made some clever runs, both overlapping and underlapping. 7
Manuel Ugarte: Got quite far forward at times, and although his two shots at goal were wayward, he had a solid game and was better with the ball. 6
Casemiro: A shadow of the player who had done so well earlier in the season. Just watched Humphreys run off him for the first goal, was booked and just too slow to react at times. 4
Bruno Fernandes: Picked a brilliant pass to create the equaliser for Sesko and wanted as much of the ball as he could get. Looked a creative force. 7
Patrick Dorgu: Playing everywhere at the moment. Something of a surprise to see him on the left but gave Kyle Walker a hard time and his cross was perfect for Sesko. 7
Matheus Cunha: Quieter than he has been in recent weeks. Struggled on the right in the first half and didn't improve much for being moved centrally. 6
Benjamin Sesko: His best game for the club. Had plenty of chances, held the ball up well, took his two goals brilliantly and forced Martin Dúbravka into another good save with a fine header. 8
Substitutes
Leny Yoro: Another centre-half change. Did fine. 6
Mason Mount: Struggled to match the impact of Fernandes. 6
Kobbie Mainoo: Came on in a deep area and tried to get on the ball. 6
Joshua Zirkzee: Couple of half chances but couldn't take them. 6
Shea Lacey: So unlucky not to score with a brilliant piece of play. 7
Subs not used: Bayindir, Maguire, Malacia, J. Fletcher

headline: Bruno Fernandes shoves ex-teammate as unseen footage shows Man United captain's true colours
body: Bruno Fernandes' leadership skills were on full display in the immediate aftermath of Manchester United's draw against Burnley. And not even former team-mate Hannibal Mejbri was safe from the midfielder's scrutiny as he sought to wind up Manuel Ugarte.

While the result didn't go Darren Fletcher's way in his first match as caretaker coach, there were positives to take from the trip to Turf Moor. Ugarte earned a start alongside Casemiro in midfield and enjoyed one of his better performances so far this season.

It was his clipped pass through to Patrick Dorgu that eventually set up Benjamin Sesko's second goal of the game. Ugarte was energetic throughout his 84-minute performance before being taken off in place of the more attack-minded Shea Lacey.

The Uruguayan had beef with Mejbri, a United academy graduate who left the club in 2024, throughout the game. And things were at risk of boiling over when he attempted to get one over on Ugarte just after the final whistle.

The Tunisia international could be seen encroaching on Ugarte's space in what was presumably an attempt to intimidate. But fan-captured footage showed Fernandes jogging over to break the pair up, shoving Mejbri away from his comrade to do so.

United's skipper showed his old colleague a discerning look as he shepherded Ugarte towards the tunnel, keeping one hand on his shoulder throughout. Lisandro Martinez also made his feelings known and appeared to give Mejbri a more vocal piece of his mind as the two groups parted.

Earlier in the game, Ugarte gave Mejbri a sarcastic pat on the back after he was booked for simulation. From that perspective, one can understand why he'd be eager to gloat after Burnley walked away the far happier team after splitting the spoils.

The 22-year-old has long had a reputation as something of a tempestuous character on the field. There were once hopes he'd be the future of United's midfield before completing his move to Burnley 18 months ago for an initial fee of around £5.5million.

As for Fernandes, the Portugal international was withdrawn on the hour mark in place of Mason Mount. Fernandes has only recently returned from a rare stint on the sidelines due to a hamstring injury, and United icon Fletcher confirmed that was always the plan.
"I didn’t want to take Bruno Fernandes off in that game," said the caretaker coach after the game. "But that was the plan from the club, from the medical [staff], from the coaches.
"Bruno had an injury, that we have to respect, and it’s a long season as well. So, it’s disappointing, but that was the plan before the game and we knew that was going to happen."

Jaidon Anthony's stunning equaliser gave Burnley a point they won't soon forget in what was a feisty encounter. But Mejbri in particular may take care in future when picking his battles against his old team.

headline: Morgan Rogers comments sends clear message to Man United dressing room about Michael Carrick
body: Aston Villa star Morgan Rogers speaks very fondly of Michael Carrick, describing him as a manager who stood out during the early stages of his career. Carrick is one of the contenders to take interim charge at Manchester United, alongside Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

Both coaches previously worked together at Old Trafford, with Carrick forming part of Solskjaer's backroom team. While there are plenty of questions about who might be best suited for the role, Rogers has already given his own verdict on Carrick.
The Villa star spent the 2023/24 season playing under Carrick at Middlesbrough and has highlighted the influence that short spell had on his career.
"Michael Carrick, he was the coach that spoke to me away from football," Rogers said.
"There was always a line of communication with him which I thought was vital at that time. I still speak to him now.
"I had a difficult three years going out on loan, before Middlesbrough, but I don't think I'd be the player I am now without the experiences.
"It gave me the toughness to go through adversity, it also helped me grow up and learn about myself and what I needed to improve. At that time, I wasn't ready."
Rogers went on: "Unai [Emery] has obviously been important with the style of play and what he's made me - the confidence he's embedded in me.
"He's allowed me to be me and really show my skills."
Carrick took his first steps in management in 2022, when he was appointed head coach of Middlesbrough in the Championship. That following a brief caretaker spell with United in 2021.
Despite recording 63 wins during his time with Boro, he was unable to take the club over the line and, ultimately, left his post in the summer of 2025.

As United continue to weigh up their next move, Darren Fletcher is currently overseeing the team in the absence of a permanent appointment. Following Wednesday's 2-2 draw at Burnley, he will take charge of Sunday's FA Cup tie against Brighton & Hove Albion (4.30pm).

headline: Fernandes, De Ligt, Mbeumo - Man United injury news and AFCON absences before Brighton FA Cup tie
body: Darren Fletcher's interim period at Manchester United is set to continue to the weekend, at the very least, with all eyes set on the FA Cup.

The competition remains the last likely option for the side to earn silverware, after a costly early exit to Grimsby Town in the Carabao Cup, and the difficulty in closing down the gap at the top of the Premier League.
Whether Fletcher remains in post beyond the weekend's clash with Brighton in the cup remains to be seen, but he will be keen to push the team through to the fourth round either way.

The make-shift backroom staff were boosted in midweek with the return of some key figures from injury, though it wasn't enough to earn victory at Burnley, as they were held to a 2-2 draw at Turf Moor.
It could be all the difference in the FA Cup for United, though, not least with three notable absences due to the Africa Cup of Nations.
So, with that said, here's a look at the injury and availability latest for the caretaker boss ahead of the match.

Defender Matthijs de Ligt remains out of action with a lower back issue. The centre-back has been out of action since November, as he looks to recover, with some hope that he could be back again soon.

Bryan Mbeumo has impressed since his move to Manchester United last summer, so his absence has been felt dearly. The forward has been away on international duty at the Africa Cup of Nations with Cameroon, who take on Morocco on Friday night for a place in the semi-final.

Another absentee due to AFCON is Noussair Mazraoui, who is with the host nation Morocco. The 28-year-old will take on Mbeumo and Cameroon in Friday's match, meaning one of the two United stars will be back in the near future.

The third and final AFCON absentee is Amad, who has been in impressive form for the Ivory Coast. The Man United ace has a mouth-watering game against Egypt on Saturday evening, as his side eyes up a place in the final four of the competition.

Manchester United were greeted with an early return for Bruno Fernandes in midweek, as he was available to start against Burnley. It remains to be seen whether he is fit enough to start against Brighton in the cup, having played an hour in the match.

Another welcome return came for Kobbie Mainoo, who came off the bench in the trip to Turf Moor. The academy graduate played the final 15 minutes of the match as he works his way back from injury, with hopes of muscling his way back into contention.

Harry Maguire was named on the bench for Man United's trip to Burnley in midweek. He has struggled with a thigh injury since November, and while he was available once again, he didn't make an appearance and his fitness for the Brighton clash is unclear.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United complete first deal of January transfer window
body: Sam Mather has been pictured in Kayserispor training kit after completing his move from Manchester United. Mather's departure represents United's first sale in the January transfer window.

Mather has signed for an undisclosed fee and has joined up with Kayserispor's training camp in Antalya. His first three games for Kayserispor will come against Besiktas, Istanbul Basaksehir and Galatasaray. Salford-born Mather decided to leave his boyhood club in favour of a fresh challenge. The 21-year-old had a contract at Old Trafford until 2027, but he wanted to compete in a professional environment.
After missing out on a summer exit, Mather had taken part in first-team training sessions at Carrington this season. The youngster made six appearances in academy fixtures to maintain match fitness.

The MEN reported in September that talks were at an advanced stage with Kayserispor on Turkey's deadline day. Kayserispor pushed hard to sign Mather on a permanent deal. The fee and buy-back clause were agreed, and it's understood personal terms were also verbally agreed with the forward.
United outlined a time for an agreement to be finalised and sign-off by the board was required, but the club eventually decided they did not have enough time to facilitate the transfer.
Kayserispor were not deterred and opened fresh talks in December to sign Mather this month. Mather leaves United with an FA Youth Cup win and 30 goals in youth league fixtures.

headline: Michael Carrick's telling Ole Gunnar Solskjaer comments as Man United speak to club icons
body: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer could be precisely what Manchester United need right now, if Michael Carrick's previous evaluation is any indication. The Norwegian has been touted for a dramatic return to Old Trafford on an interim basis following Ruben Amorim's dismissal this week.

In an official statement, United explained that the Amorim decision was taken to provide the club with the "best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish" during the season's second-half. Consequently, the board are now searching the market for an appropriate replacement, with several names emerging as contenders.

While bookmakers have identified Oliver Glasner, Enzo Maresca and Gareth Southgate as proposed long-term appointments, reports suggest United could be considering bringing in a short-term, interim head coach before evaluating their options at the season's conclusion.
Manchester United next manager LIVE - Solskjaer talks, Enrique latest, Glasner promise

Carrick and Solskjaer have emerged as potential candidates for an interim role, given both men possess previous experience leading the club and maintain excellent relationships with Old Trafford's senior management.

As such, the club are expected to meet with both individuals, to discuss a possible spell with United until the end of the 2025/2026 campaign. However, Carrick may well have inadvertently talked himself out of contention with a glowing appraisal of Solskjaer in the recent past.

Speaking in 2019, the 44-year-old said about the Norwegian: "Ole's got that personality that rubs off on everybody, he's so positive, he's so upbeat all the time. I think you can see that rubbing off on individuals, and that goes a long way to bringing the best out of the players."

Meanwhile, Darren Fletcher is set to take the reins for United's Wednesday evening fixture against Burnley, as the club aims to maintain their impressive Premier League run. It's also believed that discussions will take place with the Scot regarding the possibility of him remaining in charge until the season concludes, while Ruud van Nistelrooy has apparently been overlooked by his former employers.

According to The Mail, though the Dutchman was originally considered for the position, he has now fallen out of the frame. It comes despite Van Nistelrooy demonstrating his capabilities in October 2024 following Erik ten Hag's dismissal.

Van Nistelrooy served as interim manager for four fixtures before Amorim's arrival in November, securing three victories and one draw before departing to manage Leicester City. His spell in the Midlands proved far less successful last term, with the Foxes ultimately dropping into the Championship and parting company with the 49-year-old by mutual agreement in June.

If Solskjaer were to be named United's manager for the remainder of the campaign, the club could find itself in capable hands. The 52-year-old held the position at the club from 2018 to 2021, guiding United to sixth, third and second-place finishes in the Premier League.
Despite not securing any trophies across all competitions, his efforts in the league outshone those of David Moyes, Louis van Gaal and Ten Hag.

headline: Luis Enrique's five-word response to Man United manager job links as PSG stance clear
body: Paris Saint-Germain boss Luis Enrique once asked: "Is it April Fool's Day?" after being quizzed about taking over at Manchester United. United's sacking of Ruben Amorim has sent the rumour mill into overdrive over who could be set for the Old Trafford hot seat.
One potential candidate is PSG boss Enrique after reports emerged that the Spaniard doesn't wish to extend his contract with the French giants.

However, after Ole Gunnar Solskjaer was sacked as United boss in November 2021, Enrique, then Spain boss, was quick to shut down any links to United's vacant managerial position. Reports had linked him with the club at the time.

Recent reports had claimed Enrique could leave the Parisian club in the summer with his contract expiring amid a reported desire for a fresh challenge. If true, this would position the 55-year-old as being available in June.

However, if his playful yet terse reply to the links in 2021 are anything to go by, United could have a job on their hands if they wish to recruit the former Barcelona coach.

And in a further blow, reports he could leave the French capital have already been shot down by club chiefs. Speaking to Canal+ about the rumours on Tuesday, PSG sporting director Luis Campos simply replied: "100% fake news."
Enrique has been a huge success at PSG. He has won two league titles, the Coupe de France on two occasions and the Champions League in 2025.
His European Cup triumph is his second as manager after he won it in charge of Barcelona in 2015. He also picked up two La Liga titles with the Catalan giants.
Currently, PSG remain in all domestic cup competitions, sit second in Ligue 1 and third in the Champions League table ahead of the final two games of the league phase.
PSG started the new year with a 2-1 win over city rivals Paris FC . Speaking after the game, Enrique claimed he was looking forward to winning more silverware in Paris.

"We came back to the Parc with a victory," he said. "I hope we win as many trophies in 2026. That's our goal, which is ambitious, of course, but I think that everyone in this team, club, and our supporters are ambitious, too. We want to win trophies and that's what we're going to try to do."
Amorim was informed on Monday morning that he was being sacked and left United with immediate effect. He departed with a record of just 24 wins in 63 games.

United are understood to have held talks with Solskjaer, Michael Carrick and Ruud van Nistelrooy over taking the job on a temporary basis until the end of the season, though the latter is reported to be out of the running.

Solskjaer is a leading candidate after making it clear that he would return to Old Trafford. Darren Fletcher will take charge of United on an interim basis and will be in the dugout for the game against Burnley on Wednesday evening.

headline: When Man United could announce Ruben Amorim replacement explained as day named for agreement
body: Manchester United will reportedly make a decision on appointing Ruben Amorim’s replacement this week. United parted company with Amorim on Monday, with the Portuguese leaving Old Trafford after just 14 months in charge of the club.

Amorim’s last match at United was the 1-1 draw with Leeds United on Sunday, with the Reds now failing to win four of their last five Premier League matches and have drawn each of their last two fixtures.
Darren Fletcher has been placed in interim charge of United, with the former midfielder overseeing the coaching responsibilities for the club’s Premier League away trip to Burnley on Wednesday night.
Former United boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has been linked with a return to Old Trafford, having served as the club’s manager from 2018-21 and was most recently in charge of Besiktas.
Solskjaer is out of work once again after leaving the Turkish club in August last year, and is now being linked with a return to United once again.
Norwegian news outlet VG have provided some insight into United’s plans to appoint Solskjaer, including when they expect an announcement to be made.
It has been reported that United in negotiations over an agreement with Solskjaer to take place on Friday, although it is still unclear if this would be on a long-term or short-term deal.
The report has claimed that Solskjaer will be in Molde on Thursday to attend the funeral of Norwegian coaching legend Age Hareide, and so an agreement is unlikely to be completed before Friday.

Solskjaer became United manager in December 2018 after replacing Jose Mourinho in the Old Trafford dugout, where the appointment was initially on an interim basis before being made permanent a few months later.

After facing Burnley in the Premier League on Thursday, United will host Brighton at Old Trafford on Sunday in the third round of the FA Cup and it remains to be seen if Solskjaer will be in the dugout once again for the fixture or if it will be Fletcher or a different coach in charge.

headline: Sheikh Jassim's Manchester United wish granted after Ruben Amorim sack
body: Sheikh Jassim bin Hamad Al Thani may not have taken control at Manchester United, but elements of his vision for the club are coming to life.

The Qatari billionaire went head-to-head with Sir Jim Ratcliffe in 2023 after the Glazer family opened the door to a sale of the club. Ratcliffe ultimately prevailed, securing an initial 25 per cent stake - now increased to 28.9 per cent - in 2024, leaving Sheikh Jassim empty-handed.

However, one of the central pillars of his proposed ownership model appears to be influencing developments at Old Trafford. During the bidding process, it was widely reported that he intended to install former United players in "prominent roles" throughout the club, strengthening the connection between the boardroom and the dressing room.

Sheikh Jassim believed the lack of club icons within United's hierarchy was a missed opportunity, especially given the wealth of experience and institutional knowledge available - and the idea is now gaining traction despite his absence.

Ratcliffe, who oversees all football operations at United, has increasingly turned to former players for support over the past year. After dismissing Erik ten Hag last season, then assistant and club legend Ruud van Nistelrooy was appointed as interim head coach.

That approach has now been repeated following Ruben Amorim's departure this week, with another former United stalwart, Under-18s boss Darren Fletcher, placed in temporary charge of the first team. Fletcher has also been joined on the coaching staff by his former United team-mate Jonny Evans, who only departed from his role as head of loans and pathways last month.

Beyond the current setup, Ratcliffe is once again looking to United's past as he weighs up short-term solutions in the dugout. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, who managed United between 2018 and 2021, is in talks over a potential interim return, while former midfielder Michael Carrick is also under consideration.

Amorim was sacked on Monday following a fiery outburst after United's 0-0 draw with Leeds the day before. During a heated post-match press conference, the 40-year-old insisted he was the "manager" of the club, not merely the head coach - a remark that hinted at tension with the hierarchy.
His 14-month tenure proved a major disappointment. Amorim won just 38 per cent of his games in charge, the lowest for any permanent United manager since Frank O'Farrell in the early 1970s.

The Portuguese coach also presided over much of one of the club's worst domestic campaigns in decades, culminating in a 15th-place Premier League finish last season. They were also beaten in the Europa League final, missing out on a route back into the Champions League.

Yet despite the setbacks, Amorim leaves the team in comparatively decent shape. At the time of writing, United sit sixth in the table - their highest position under him - and are just three points off the top four.
With the club now turning to familiar faces for help, the stage is set for a period of transition that could redefine United's immediate future.

headline: How Manchester United should line up vs Burnley in Darren Fletcher's first game in charge
body: A fresh era for Manchester United starts this evening when Darren Fletcher takes charge of the Reds for their trip to Burnley in the Premier League. The Scot has moved up to the United first team following the sacking of Ruben Amorim on Monday morning.

Unfortunately for Fletcher, he has limited options to choose from to try and get a much-needed victory tonight. Amad, Noussair Mazraoui and Bryan Mbeumo remain unavailable due to their participation at the Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON). As for injuries, captain Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount trained on Tuesday and are available tonight.

Their minutes will be managed as they return to full match fitness but it is a boost for the Reds to have two players in such good form back available. Matthijs de Ligt and Harry Maguire are out due to injury issues and Kobbie Mainoo faces a late fitness test.
Our United writers have had their say on how they think United should line up tonight:
Tyrone Marshall

First thing's first, let's forget about a back three. It would be quite the plot twist if Fletcher decided he wanted to stick with Amorim's doomed formation. That means Dalot at right-back and Shaw at left-back, while I would stick with Heaven and Martinez at centre-back.

Returning players in midfield means Ugarte can drop to the bench. Casemiro can play the holding role with Fernandes and Mount ahead of him, although there are doubts over whether either can make 90 minutes.
Dorgu can play on the right wing, as he did successfully against Newcastle, with Cunha on the left, and Sesko is through the middle.
Jack Flintham

It makes sense now the Amorim era has ended to revert to a four-man defence. I would start Fernandes. United need a lift after everything that has happened over the past few days and seeing the captain return would give them just that.

The chances of him lasting 90 minutes are very slim but it would set the tone. Playing him deeper could be the safe option and recalling Zirkzee, who provided a great assist for Cunha at Leeds, could be a wise option.

headline: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's incredible £4m Cheshire home with pool and celebrity neighbours
body: Manchester United are on the hunt for a new manager once again following the sacking of Ruben Amorim, as the hierarchy ponder their next move.

While Darren Fletcher is in post for now, Man United could turn to the familiar face of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, who enjoyed a famous interim period with the club before landing the role as manager on a full-time basis.

Reports surrounding talks over a short-term deal for the Norwegian coach could see him 'back at the wheel' once more, while the 52-year-old was spotted back in Cheshire, where he has owned a £4m home.

The property is based in Alderley Edge, where plenty of famous stars have decided to settle - including Manchester City's Erling Haaland and Coleen and Wayne Rooney, while Victoria and David Beckham and Cristiano Ronaldo also lived in the area in the past - while celebrities such as Christine McGuinness and Kerry Katona have been spotted living in the area.
Solskjaer bought his property, which was originally a cottage, and transformed it into an "eco mansion", which began building in 2007.
It took some time for the former Manchester United man to move in with his family, having spent time in Norway after his playing career came to an end.
That had led to him putting it up on the market, but when it wasn't sold, reports claimed that he rented it out to Liverpool star Virgil van Dijk.
Solskjaer eventually moved into the property fully in 2019, when returning to Old Trafford, with the mansion featuring 3.4 acres of land around it.

When put on the market back in 2016, the brochure provided by estate agents described the features of the property, which said: "[The property] is an impressive contemporary style recently constructed detached family residence in extensive grounds of approximately 3.4 acres with impressive leisure complex with pool.

"[It] is a charming quiet, cobbled road on the outskirts of Alderley Edge enjoying a delightful rural setting. The village centre which is within a few minutes drive offers an excellent range of shopping, educational and recreational facilities with a wealth of quality cafes and fine restaurants."
The estate agent added: "[The home] enjoys extensive mature grounds surrounding the property with sweeping lawns, mature trees and shrubs with open views beyond.
"Natural wood electrically operated double gates to the front where a sweeping gravel driveway provides excellent parking facilities and leads to an attached garage."
There is also a pool room in the house, along with a media room, similar to those seen in some footballer's houses that will often feature cinema rooms.
With Solskjaer believed to still own the property, and spotted back in Cheshire, there is a possibility he and his family could move back into the house if he is called in for the interim spell.

headline: Senne Lammens 'can become the best in the world' - Manchester United have a new star
body: Senne Lammens wore a polo shirt and a navy sweatshirt when he visited Old Trafford after signing for Manchester United. The young goalkeeper looked as though he could be joining United to work in their HR department.
The same observation was made when Lammens reported for international duty with Belgium last week - the 23-year-old was dressed in a beige collared jacket, a khaki t-shirt and chinos.

"By accident, I saw an article saying he was wearing something boring when he reported for international duty and fans saying they hoped he stays like this," laughed Hayk Milkon, one of Lammens' former coaches.
"This 'boringness' is just the way Senne is, he's really calm and no excesses. He focuses on what he needs to focus on and is open with the people around him. He keeps his feet on the ground."

If Lammens looks like someone who could work in an office, every workplace would love to have him in their five-a-side team. United believe they have signed a young goalkeeper with huge potential, and fans who were present at Old Trafford against Sunderland left the stadium buzzing about his debut.
The quirk is that Lammens appears to be a different person when he wears his goalkeeper kit. He made a supremely confident United debut, aggressively commanded his area and kept a clean sheet.
Milkon coached Lammens during their time together at Club Brugge. Milkon is now the youngest manager in the Belgian top-flight and Lammens plays for the biggest club in England.
"It was Senne with his headphones on. He would go into the gym to do his recovery or some extra top-ups. Or he would just go to relax by playing basketball - he loved to play basketball."

Milkon coached in different roles at Club Brugge. He was the assistant of Club NXT (their reserve team), served as their interim manager, was in charge of the Under-18s and eventually became a first-team coach.
His time at Club Brugge coincided with Lammens progressing from the academy to their first team, so he is uniquely positioned to provide insight into United's new goalkeeper signing.

Lammens joined Club Brugge's academy when he was 12. "He was a guy with huge potential," said Milkon. "As I learned from colleagues who had worked with him when he was much younger, I heard there was a moment that clicked in his head when he became super professional.
"He was one of the guys during Covid - when the players were not able to train - who was doing a lot at home, he was really going far with this to be the best in these types of areas.
"Then he continued like this when he joined the first team to train with them. He always wanted to improve. We also had something in place to look at the parameters on which goalkeepers are judged.
"You see the potential of the goalkeeper based on what they do in games; so their positioning, their decision-making and so on, and Senne was always quite high in these areas.
"The only bad luck that he had was that the first-team goalkeeper was Simon Mignolet. He's an amazing goalkeeper, so it was difficult for Senne to stay over there in the role of No.2.
"That would have also blocked his growth, so it was good for him in the end to make the step to go to Antwerp and he did a tremendous job there. It was amazing to see how fast he adapted."
Milkon continued: "I think for us at Club Brugge, it was very clear to everyone that Senne was a top goalkeeper. He would have been the perfect fit for Club Brugge to be the No.1.
"That was not possible because Mignolet was there. But the parameters that we used to judge his performances indicated he was ticking so many boxes already, and he was consistently doing it.

"There weren't ups and downs with his performances. He was consistently really high and when you compare this to the top goalkeepers, you have a benchmark to say 'Ok, what potential does this guy have?'
"He had some chances with the first team at Club Brugge and made a mistake, or maybe two, but in the end it was very clear to everyone that he was a top goalkeeper.
"It was impossible to try to extend his contract because, again, you have Mignolet, and you cannot block a guy like this. You know he has to go out, he has to play, and he will improve even more."

When asked about Lammens' strengths, he said: "I would say that his decision-making was very good. He is very calm, he sees the solutions on the pitch, he has a quick reaction time and understands the balance between risk and reward, and which decisions are the right ones to make.

"His clean passing is great, his footwork was really good, and he's just an amazing goalkeeper with the shot-stopping. He made some incredible saves back then already. He's quite a complete goalkeeper.
"But making the right decisions at a very young age, being very mature with this, was really impressive. And the fact that he is good with both feet is another big strength.
"For me, Senne is a very calm guy and has all the qualities to be a top professional. That was my impression when I first met him when he was younger and he never changed."

Lammens joined Royal Antwerp on a free transfer in the summer of 2023. He was handed his debut a few months later and served as an understudy that season, but earned first-choice status for 2024/2025.
His performances drew attention from the Belgian media. Lammens saved four penalties across a successful first full campaign and received a call-up to Belgium's senior squad in March.

Milkon said: "I was not surprised when I saw Manchester United had come calling. And to record his first clean sheet, I was really happy for him. Senne is a potential No.1 for the Red Devils - the Belgium national team.

"He got his chance, he took it, and we're all really proud of him, but we knew it would happen. I believe he has all the capabilities to become the best in the world, so I wish him all the best. I'm sure he will have a very good career in England, and Manchester United should return to the big club they used to be.
"He will have a positive impact on that, for sure, and hopefully he will be Belgium's first-choice goalkeeper soon. I believe he has the potential, the skillset and the personality to do that.
"For me, it was just having a tiny little part in having an influence on him at Brugge, but it was the most positive memories of our relationship that we had during this spell.

"I'm very proud that he is reaching these high levels and not surprised. I believe he will be successful because he is a guy who will not change his focus or start to do something different. He is calm, that's his personality and character, and he wants to succeed. He is hungry and will keep working to be his best.

"He is so calm, and you have to be patient in football. You cannot worry too much and want things too early, but finding the balance between not being impatient and, at the same time, pushing and demanding what you deserve in a good way, means everything will sort itself out."
United staff who have worked with Lammens at Carrington have echoed Milkon's sentiments. He has been described as "really mature for his age" and is said to have taken the move in his stride.

Lammens is understood to have impressed coaches during training sessions and a United source said that lots of people have been speaking positively about him. He has already relocated from the luxury hotel where he was initially staying and into a house.
It's no surprise that Lammens likes to play basketball at 6ft 3in, but he is a keen golfer, which is common ground with the likes of Tom Heaton, Luke Shaw, Mason Mount and Harry Maguire.

Matthijs de Ligt, Amad, Maguire and Shaw jogged straight to Lammens to congratulate him after full-time against Sunderland. "Are you Schmeichel in disguise?" was chanted at Lammens from the Stretford End.
It remains to be seen whether Lammens will start against Liverpool on Sunday, but it would be a surprise to see him on the bench after delivering a strong debut before the international break.
There would be nothing boring about keeping another clean sheet - this time at Anfield.

Frank has turned Spurs into more of a defensive unit this term and they initially benefited from this change, but performances and results have massively declined in recent months.
The north London outfit have only won one of their previous 13 matches in all competitions as Frank has alienated himself with his uninspiring tactics and odd outbursts in press conferences.

“It is my job to deal with scrutiny. I will take all the questions and the blame. It is also my job to look through everything and look through the defeat last night. It was emotional but in many ways it was good and we deserve more.

headline: Man Utd star targeted for transfer to Euro giants as Romano issues ‘still pushing’ update
body: Manchester United striker Joshua Zirkzee is still on the radar of Roma, according to Fabrizio Romano, who said a January move could be on the cards.
The 24-year-old Dutchman only joined United in 2024 but nine goals in 64 games is not exactly the kind of form that would result in a long stay.
The Old Trafford to Italy route is a well-trodden one, with Scott McTominay and Rasmus Hojlund both at Napoli and Roma could become another home to an ex-United player.
According to transfer reporter Romano, Roma have reignited their interest in the Dutchman and could go for a move in January.
“Roma are still pushing for Joshua Zirkzee,” he told GiveMeSport. “They are still there. They are still calling. So let’s see what happens with the exits.

headline: ‘Favourite’ Enrique ‘close to joining’ Man Utd with Real Madrid star made his ‘priority’ target – report
body: According to reports, Paris Saint-Germain boss Luis Enrique has emerged as the ‘favourite’ to be Ruben Amorim’s permanent replacement at Manchester United.
The Red Devils are planning to appoint an interim replacement for Amorim before bringing in a permanent successor ahead of next season.

Club legends Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Michael Carrick are currently the leading contenders to take over until the summer, though a decision on Amorim’s short-term replacement has reportedly been ‘delayed’.
By taking this route, Man Utd have a greater chance of appointing a high-level manager in the long term, as there are likely to be more bosses available in the summer.

Oliver Glasner, Andoni Iraola, Thomas Tuchel and Mauricio Pochettino are among those linked with Man Utd as possible long-term solutions, but they are said to be plotting an audacious move for Enrique.
READ: Manchester United manager candidate removed after Ferguson disciple streak broken
Enrique is regarded as one of the best managers in the world and he realistically has the pick of any club in the world when he opts for a fresh start away from PSG.
This includes better jobs than the shambles at Man Utd, so supporters of the Premier League giants should not hold their breath in anticipation of this coming off.
Enrique’s current PSG contract is due to expire in 2027, but it has been suggested that he could leave the Champions League holders this year.
With that, a report from Spanish outlet Defensa Central claims Man Utd are leading the race to appoint Enrique, who is ‘close to joining’ as the ‘favourite’ to succeed Amorim.
Why is a Spanish website, which is renowned for its unreliability and its affiliation with Real Madrid, reporting on a manager potentially swapping PSG for Man Utd, I hear you ask?

He said: “Manchester United will immediately start internal conversations about their future head coach while the caretaker is in place,” Romano said.

headline: Man Utd: Solskjaer, Carrick ‘increasingly unlikely’ update emerges for one reason as decision ‘delayed’
body: A new update has emerged as Manchester United considers whether to appoint Ole Gunnar Solskjaer or Michael Carrick as their new interim manager.
The Red Devils have been without a permanent manager since they decided to part ways with their former boss Ruben Amorim on Monday morning.
Amorim‘s position became untenable as performances and results suffered by the head coach naively refusing to adapt, while he also clashed with club chiefs over recruitment.

Since his exit, it has emerged that the Premier League giants are looking to appoint an interim boss until the summer, at which point they will look to bring in a more established manager for a long-term project.

Club legend Darren Fletcher is currently in charge, but his chances of being given the job until the summer were harmed on Wednesday night as Man Utd slipped to a disappointing 2-2 draw against Burnley.

Following that result, it has emerged that Solskjaer and Carrick are in a fight to earn the Man Utd job until the summer.

Carrick, who has since earned managerial experience at Middlesbrough, previously worked under Solskjaer at Man Utd as an assistant, with it reported by The Guardian that they could work together again.

‘If Berrada and Wilcox decide to appoint Solskjær and he becomes the caretaker manager for a second time, following his spell of December 2018 to March 2019, it is thought Carrick would consider being his assistant.’
The same report has revealed INEOS’ decision on a manager has been ‘delayed’, with Fletcher set to remain in charge for Sunday’s match against Brighton.

Both Carrick and Solskjaer have had personal commitments this week which have delayed progress, but it’s thought United’s bosses are in no rush to make a final decision, and want further talks in the coming days.

‘They have been impressed with the current interim, Darren Fletcher, both in terms of how he has conducted himself in the media and around the Carrington training ground, and the rapport he has quickly built up with the squad – many of whom are already well known to him.’

headline: Premier League sack race: Nuno and Frank in a grim race to the bottom
body: The Premier League has gone a little bit sack crazy. Managergeddon is upon us and we are entirely here for the drama.

Five clubs have changed manager since September. One has already done so twice, and another may very well be about to follow that path. When that happens Nuno Espirito Santo will have lost not one but two Premier League jobs within mere months of getting Nottingham Actual Forest into Europe.

It is a wild ride and, at the top/bottom of this particularly vomit-inducing rollercoaster it now appears to be a straight fight between Nuno and the impossibly beleaguered Thomas Frank, whose latest crime is wandering around Bournemouth with a little Arsenal coffee cup in his hands. And – this bit feels important – serving up some of the least watchable football on Premier League record.

Frank, of course, only moved to Spurs in the summer to replace Ange Postecoglou who has already been hired and sacked by Nottingham Forest, while the true lay of the land at big clubs is laid bare by the fact two of the Big Six have binned off managers not for unacceptable results on the pitch but for unacceptable failure to acknowledge infallible wisdom and brilliance of the boardroom suits. It is immensely modern football and there is almost zero chance we’ve seen the last of the managergeddon for the season. Not by a long chalk.
Meanwhile, here are possible replacement managers currently between jobs, and one of whom could, if they’re not careful, accidentally end up manager of Tottenham before the season is out.
Rankings based on the latest best prices available at Oddschecker.com…

An earlier version of this oft-updated piece speculated on what might happen to Mikel Arteta should Arsenal suffer from their Nightmare Start. What if they lost a few early games? What then? We concluded this:

It’s far likelier that Arsenal emerge blinking into the autumn sunshine broadly unscathed from their nightmare horrors. No denying that this season does represent one in which Arteta might completely lose the plot and go entirely off the rails. Or the one where he wins the league by 10 points. Feels like we’re odds-on to get one or the other.
Arsenal emerged duly unscathed, and cashed in on the shift to easier fixtures of their own alongside much tougher ones for Liverpool to take top spot and control in the Premier League.

Only question that remains, therefore, is what Arsenal do from here. We are absolutely certain that it either involves p*ssing the league by 10 points or a complete and total meltdown. Nothing in between is acceptable or even conceivable. Both options now appear gloriously possible, but current forecasts clearly point more to the former.
READ: Who will be the next manager of Arsenal if Mikel Arteta is sacked?
Doing so well that even suffering the ultimate embarrassment of defeat at Old Trafford hasn’t dampened spirits for the most impressive promoted club in quite some time.

Seven wins in the bag already and more points than any of the promoted-relegated teams managed in the entirety of 24/25. Widespread expectation that tougher games would bring Sunderland back down with a bump have thus far proved wide of the mark; there won’t be many teams unhappy at taking four points from two games against Chelsea and Arsenal this season. The comeback victory over Bournemouth was evidence, if indeed it was still required, that Sunderland are proper.
Success against Newcastle on derby day has us firmly into ‘manager of the year’ territory for one of the big pre-season Sack Race favourites.

Extraordinary season for Emery already. Began the campaign right at the outside of this market with your Artetas and – unlikely as it now sounds – Slots. Then jumped right up to third favourite when Villa’s rankling disappointment at how last season ended leaked into a six-match winless start to this campaign.

But then along came four Premier League wins in a row to thoroughly lift the mood at a club where a few short weeks earlier it really did feel like they’d come to the end of something special without ever getting the definitive moment of success it deserved.

That run reached 12 wins in 13 Premier League games to lift Villa right through the mid-table slop, then into the top four, and then genuine title contention. And for the first 45 minutes at the Emirates it really did look like they might stick around for much longer.

They didn’t and haven’t. But let’s not pretend that ‘slipping out of likely title contention’ is some kind of catastrophe for Villa. However disappointing that second half collapse was, they ended 2025 in a stunning place.
Five wins in six games have a distinctly winnable Europa League campaign bubbling along nicely, too. An astonishing shift from what felt like an inexorable downward spiral not that long ago.
We could all learn something from that, but we won’t.

The continuity candidate in the summer, and looked to have received the ultimate hospital pass. How much continuity could there be at Brentford given they’d sold Bryan Mbeumo, Yoane Wissa and Christian Norgaard, while Thomas Frank took most of the remaining coaching staff with him to Tottenham? It was a very Brentford move to promote from within and we’ll hold our hands up and admit we thought it would go far, far worse than it has.

With Newcastle and Sunderland added to Liverpool and Manchester United on the list of Gtech victims this season, it’s an undeniably impressive effort in trying circumstances, lifting Brentford all the way for now into what is very likely a Champions League-qualifying position.
That Brentford now sit a whole six points clear of their former manager and his supposedly greener pastures is quite something.

Fine end to 24/25 put a different complexion on Brighton’s season than at one time appeared likely. Ending up a clear best of the rest outside the quickly established top seven represented at least a passing grade and they’d have had to make a truly awful start to the season to get in any kind of managerial-change bother.

The win over Newcastle to go with victory at Chelsea to go with a win over City reaffirmed Brighton’s big-boy-bothering calibre, but does also make some of their other results – draws with Fulham and Spurs (from 2-0 up) and Wolves and West Ham (twice), for instance – a bit annoying.

We still subscribe to the view that every team between seventh and 14th is equally good/bad and that no major judgement for good or bad should be based on whichever arbitrary position has been handed to them this week.

Backed in to a hot favourite as the whispers began before the international break. But just when we thought it might be time to accept something is fundamentally broken here as a relegation fight bubbled up, an impressive win over Sunderland and a restorative visit to Tottenham have sorted things out.

Six wins and two draws in 10 Premier League games since the November international break have lifted Fulham well away from the relegation battle and into the mid-table strivers, significantly lessening the real risk that either Silva or Fulham might do something they live to regret.
A sacking remains out of the question despite last season’s (relative) struggles. There hasn’t been a Premier League manager since Fergie in his pomp with more credit in the bank than Pep.

But is there still a distinct chance Guardiola decides he’s had enough and simply walks away? We reckon there is as they eye ‘two’ alternatives, and it’s always worth remembering that we’re talking Next Premier League Manager To Leave here, and that the traditional ‘Sack Race’ shorthand is a bit misleading.

If, as now seems likely, City are unable to muster a meaningful challenge to Arsenal at the summit, it’s not impossible to imagine a scenario where Champions League failure prompts Guardiola to sod it all for a game of soldiers. Crucially, though, there is still almost no chance of any of that coming to pass before at least one of the genuine misery-guts clubs pressing the panic button.

A 4-1 thumping of Everton followed a simply huge and wildly unexpected win over Manchester City. Had Newcastle lost that, as all pre-interlull indications suggested they would, then the spotlight would have been harsh indeed on Howe and his team. They would at that point find themselves slap bang in the muck of a relegation scrap; instead they have lifted themselves back into the mid-table morass and – with absolutely nobody in there being actually any good at all – have now managed to get themselves right to the very top of it, firmly back into the Champions League equation, via nothing more complicated than three straight wins.
The 4-3 victory over Leeds was admittedly quite complicated, but also just tremendously exciting. Pure Newcastle heritage.

Sounds preposterous, but there really is a non-zero chance Moyes gets punished for easing Everton’s immediate relegation fears and they seek some more enterprising football from a squad that is, in fairness, capable of that as climbing into the top six demonstrates. Does feel like a very familiar Everton story, though, and one that ends with them 16th, chastened, and bringing in another firefighter.
Still among the least sackable managers in the top flight despite Bournemouth now being in the depths of one of the familiar lows that have always existed alongside the highs under Iraola.

A streaky manager of a streaky team, but he must still be in credit overall given the prognostications of doom when he had to sell pretty much his entire defence in the summer. It’s hurting him and Bournemouth now but they still – for now, just about – remain outside the real relegation scrap and that’s impressive enough on the back of such a challenging summer.

But after an 11-game run without a win, he and Bournemouth desperately needed something to kickstart another of those runs of Champions League form. And sure enough, along came Dr Tottenham with the prescription, and Antoine Semenyo with a wonderful parting gift.
Might actually have made Wolves… quite good? Certainly a lot less bad, anyway. It is still almost certainly too little, too late, but that’s also not really Rob Edwards’ fault either.

The first win of the season was a cathartic dismantling of a doom-laden West Ham, and it didn’t come out of a clear blue sky either. There had been signs of life even in defeat at Arsenal and Liverpool, before running away giggling from Old Trafford with a point.

After a draw at Everton, it’s now five points from their last three games. That’s a pretty big deal when you’ve only managed two from the previous 18 games, and suddenly Wolves find themselves as close to West Ham as West Ham do to safety.

Stranger things have happened, but admittedly not many. And most of them in the actual Stranger Things. On balance, Wolves would also probably rather believe in a wild conspiracy theory that suggests this current season has actually been entirely fake and that the real ending is yet to be revealed.

Has done more than could ever have been expected given the chaos he walked into. That epic pants-pulling at Anfield and joyful spangling of Tottenham should be enough to buy any manager coming into a relegation-haunted club serious time.

But Mr Marinakis’ lair is never a safe place for any manager to lurk, and there have been a pair of honking defeats against Everton and a weirdly rubbish performance against Brighton as well that will have had one of 2025’s key supervillains twitching over his big red sack button once more.
Looked in very serious trouble when trailing at half-time against West Ham; Forest’s first win in a Premier League game they’d been losing at half-time since 1997 was enormously well timed.

The hard-nosed yet valid argument persists that Leeds could and perhaps should have taken drastic action in the summer even after their very good week. It would have made Spurs’ decision to sack Europa League-winning Ange Postecoglou look positively kind, Leeds – and Burnley for that matter – might now be better off had they thanked the managers who secured 100 Championship points and got them back into the big time and then sent them on their way.
Farke had a dreadful Premier League record of only six wins and 26 points from his 49 games in charge of Norwich, a team he twice led to promotion from the Championship with 94 and 97 points.

As well as fighting his own record in this competition, Farke faced the added burden of expectation levels very different to those at just about any other club that could possibly find itself promoted into the Premier League in this current era where that represents the most bittersweet of successes.

Defeat at Burnley was honking, but bouncing back to win another six-pointer against West Ham eased the stress significantly before a paddling at Brighton and events elsewhere – including West Ham themselves – left Farke desperately short of immediate cover before a desperately poor show in a six-pointer at Nottingham Forest.

Another painful defeat having gone in front, against Villa this time, saw Leeds drop into the bottom three ahead of a brutal run of games, but that run has gone surprisingly well. The narrow loss to Man City preceded a rare home win against Chelsea and comeback draw against Liverpool.

The question now is whether Leeds and Farke have really hit on something sustainable, or this is merely delaying the inevitable. After the 4-1 win against Crystal Palace and a very decent point at Sunderland, it really does start to look like it might be the latter which has enormous repercussions for both Farke and several other names around him on this list.

Enormously impressive even in heartbreaking defeat at Newcastle in a wild 4-3 that earned instant classic status. Key now is to ensure that it doesn’t throw them off course, because once the initial pain subsides there is no reason why it should.

Impossible to avoid the conclusion that Slot’s reaction to Liverpool’s mini-crisis becoming actual-crisis was poor. He went Full Klopp with his salty loser behaviour when Manchester United committed the crime of altering their tactics to give themselves the best chance of success against Liverpool, and the headloss continued after another chaotic and unstructured performance led to a 3-2 defeat at Brentford.

Having ticked ‘opposition doing tactics wrong’ off his rattled manager bingo card, he can now add ‘losing his mind over entirely uncontroversial refereeing decisions’ with his response to both the Cody Gakpo non-penalty and Virgil van Dijk penalty at the Gtech.

It has to be a worry for Liverpool that Slot has for the first time in his Anfield career found himself under any kind of pressure after a chastening run of defeats, and has suffered severe and instant headloss as a result.

Funny to think of a manager who’s just beaten Real Madrid in the Champions League being under threat, but defeat at the Etihad was miserable before Nottingham Forest came along and achieved the amusing feat of being the first team to shut Liverpool out in the Premier League at Anfield since Nottingham Forest.

And then there was a new nadir against PSV. That really was very, very bad. West Ham were wonderfully welcoming hosts on Sunday, but to such an inexplicable extent that it’s hard to know just how much to read into Liverpool’s 2-0 win at the London Stadium against opponents who were barely there. Predictably, they were poor in a 1-1 against proper team Sunderland and showed no backbone in the collapse at Leeds United, which was then followed by a distinctly unwelcome MO SALAH BOMBSHELL that does leave things looking distinctly like either he or the manager will have to go.

A run of four consecutive wins cooled the immediate temperatures, but it does all feel extremely precarious. The wins over Spurs and Wolves have lacked any real authority. And then there were careless draws against Leeds and Fulham.
Arsenal next, and a non-zero chance that any repeat of the Etihad capitulation in the face of the only compellingly good team in the league could spell the end.
Won’t be sacked, obviously, because Palace are absolutely punching with an elite-level manager who is quietly delivering astonishing results in trying circumstances.

But he’s currently among the names being considered by Manchester United for the permanent manager’s job that is set to be available this summer. And that’s before we mention Liverpool and Spurs. He really does deserve a crack at a big job; it’s just a shame really that they are all, in their way, so very silly.
Decision time for Burnley. There are two options available, and they prompt inevitable questions.
Option one: Burnley decide to really try and beat relegation, and must decide whether they think Parker is the best man for that job.
Option two: Burnley accept their overwhelmingly likely fate, and must decide whether Parker the best man to get them back up again.
Parker’s job prospects likely rest on the decision. Because if it is indeed option two, he has a compelling case. Option one? He’s f*cked.
But the longer he remains in place, the greater the chance that option two is the one. And right now he’s doing just enough to keep the wolves (literal and figurative) from the door.

There have been good days and bad, and our whole pondering of Frank’s situation at Spurs has been about determining which of the two would eventually win out. The harrowing NLD-PSG-Fulham week was the first time he really did look f*cked.

Spurs were timid and abysmal in the North London Derby, the second big London derby in a row which Frank had approached more in the manner of a League One manager attempting to avoid a paddling in the FA Cup third round than a legitimate rival facing a familiar foe.

There was some encouragement in a 5-3 Champions League defeat at PSG, but even the very fact it’s possible to write the words ‘some encouragement in a 5-3 Champions League defeat’ is in its own way damning.

But at least those two defeats came against what genuinely might be the two best teams in Europe at this time. With all due respect to Fulham and the sterling work of Marco Silva in recent years, they are not one of the two best teams in Europe at this time, and they were still much better than Spurs who torpedoed themselves inside the opening seven minutes to extend their extraordinarily – and in fairness largely pre-Frank – awful home record in the Premier League to three wins in 21 games since an increasingly odd-looking 4-1 win over Aston Villa in November last year.
Frank’s response to the booing of Guglielmo Vicario after his hideous blunder was firmly in the ‘That’s true, but he shouldn’t say it’ category. And the way he went about it was all wrong.

There should have been some acknowledgement that the booing of Vicario, unsavoury and unhelpful as it may have been, did not burst forth from a clear blue sky but instead a bubbling frustration from fans who pay among the highest ticket prices in the country to watch what is now among the worst and least effective football in the country.

To instead label those supporters – and the boos did not come from a tiny minority inside the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium – not real Spurs fans was another gaffe that pushes the manager further towards the exit.
Until that point we’d felt the obvious comparisons between Thomas Frank and Nuno Espirito Santo didn’t quite fit.

But it’s certainly starting to look uncomfortably similar in familiar ways; the small-time approach to big games has not been well received and the fear grows that he just doesn’t understand what this job requires. The fact almost no manager in Premier League history has managed to understand what this job requires is cold comfort at this time.

However, from there Spurs went to Newcastle and got a draw (albeit a ludicrous one) before they had a dominant 2-0 win against Frank’s old club Brentford, which everyone at Spurs sorely needed. It was easily their most convincing Premier League performance since the win at City on matchday two and a result that could have been even more compelling.
They then pretty much secured a Champions League play-off round spot at the very least with a fine 3-0 win over Slavia Prague.
But Spurs are Spurs, so they followed that with the worst performance yet of Frank’s reign in a truly inept and miserable 3-0 defeat at Nottingham Forest.
Bringing Joao Palhinha and Ben Davies on to try and hold on to a 2-0 defeat and not even managing that feels uncomfortably like the infamous Nuno Moment against Manchester United.

Have reached the kind of state where a dreadful home defeat to a very poor Liverpool is being dressed up as ‘signs of encouragement’. In reality, it might have been the worst possible result; still a defeat, yet one that risks extending the increasingly obviously doomed reign of the latest manager to be chewed up and spat out by the country’s most preposterous football club.

The win at Palace was welcome if deeply unconvincing, while the sheer small-timery of a mind-meltingly dull goalless draw at Brentford really might have hurt Frank more than any of the many, many defeats. Or at least we thought that before they somehow contrived to Dr Tottenham their way to a 3-2 defeat at a Bournemouth side on a horrific streak while Frank was holding an Arsenal-branded cup.

That and the fact the winning goal was scored by Antoine Semenyo with his last kick for Bournemouth before toddling off to pass the next two years on Man City’s bench were just the latest reminders that Spurs are a club where ridiculous things happen routinely, and that Frank simply isn’t and never will be capable of dealing with that.

And in a strange way, that’s to his credit. It does look like Spurs are determined to try and muddle through the season with the obviously doomed Frank at the wheel, and in an odd way his immediate future might have more to do with West Ham than Spurs. It really might take signs of life from across the capital and genuine, mortal danger of relegation to rouse the Spurs suits from their current slumbers. Although Cristian Romero has had a go there too.
READ: Ten reasons why it’s going wrong for Thomas Frank’s Spurs – and it’s going to get worse
It’s been quite a year for Nuno. He ended 2024 as our manager of the year; he ended 2025 looking in imminent danger of his second sacking of the season.

Seven points from three games against Newcastle, Burnley and Bournemouth left things looking far comfier than might have been expected for a manager who, when the Magpies took an early lead at the London Stadium, looked to be heading for a second sack of the season long before the Christmas decorations went up.

But quite why Nuno had to be so very Nuno in the way he, on the back of 3-1 and 3-2 wins and a 2-2 draw, decided to approach a home game against a Liverpool team that had just suffered three consecutive three-goal defeats, is puzzling, irritating and, above all, a reminder that he is here as a firefighter and that the marriage to a fanbase with limited patience for drab and functional let’s-not-get-relegated football is merely one of convenience.

Especially as we still await truly compelling evidence that this football won’t, in fact get them relegated. They are in the bottom three and a long, long way adrift of safety after a rotten defeat to Nottingham Forest, who sit just the other side of the trapdoor but now a chasm-like seven points away.
